Award.AwardTitle: Supplemental funds to enhance U.S. student participation at River Flow 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will facilitate the attendance of graduate students to the International
Conference of Fluvial Hydraulics (River Flow) 2016 being held at Saint Louis University. Increased graduate student participation will infuse the perspectives of early career scientists into the conference and provide them with networking opportunities. This conference enhances the infrastructure for research and education by bringing together groups from industry and academia. It also promotes international collaboration among scientists.

The International Conference of Fluvial Hydraulics was established in 2002 by the International Association for Hydro-Environment Engineering and Research. It covers a range of topics in fluvial research. These topics are relevant to both the NSF Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics Program and the Hydrological Sciences Program. Promoting the attendance of early career scientists to this conference will advance the goal of these programs to recruit and train the next generation of geomorphologists and hydrologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to augment graduate student attendance at the June 2016 International Association for Hydro-Environmental Engineering and Research (IAHR) River Flow Fluvial Engineering conference, hosted at Saint Louis University. We achieved this through subsidizing student registration fees and travel costs to the Saint Louis area for those attending. Funds were individually awarded to 15 graduate students applying for support with conference registration. In addition, travel costs for 12 students' arriving from distant locations were also subsidized. During the conference, graduate students participated in a round table discussion regarding the best practices of establishing a local Young Professional Network (YPN) chapter at their home universities if one did not already exist as well as suggestions for possible events that would promote growth and attendance. The YPN event at River Flow also featured Dr. Peter Goodwin, president of the IAHR, who spoke on the future of fluvial engineering. In addition to Dr. Goodwin's talk, the students were provided refreshments during an icebreaker, facilitating social networking between all 80 fluvial engineers from various international locations.  Connecting with peers and discovering future opportunities are two important facets in developing a scientific career; the professional development enabled by this grant will have a lasting impact on the students in supported, as they progress with their future endeavors.
